awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for DEmocratizing Manufacturing Accessibility for Designers (DEMAND)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program.  Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research. 

The vision for the Engineering Research Center (ERC) for Democratizing Manufacturing Accessibility for Designers (DEMAND) is offer the potential for every designer to fabricate any product seamlessly and intuitively regardless of: 1) expertise or background, 2) connection with manufacturing firms, and 3) product volume (from one of a kind to millions). This vision will be achieved by breaking the deep information "asymmetry" in the existing manufacturing ecosystem and establishing a new Cloud-centric platform on which the designers' ideas and needs can be matched, in real time, with manufacturers' capabilities and capacities. 

The realization of this ERC vision will democratize manufacturing so that designers of all capabilities, including laypeople, will be empowered to see their ideas realized as useful products. Interested parties will be able to engage in manufacturing activities that can help serve the needs of our evolving society. This framework, in partnership with small and medium businesses, will also help to increase manufacturing output and support the engineering education of our future workforce. The convergent research and collective talent associated with the effort will also be used to explore and create an inclusive environment for underrepresented groups and women.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
This Engineering Research Center Planning Grant supported a series of workshops to address the theme - DEmocratizing Manufacturing Accessibility for Designers (DEMAND). DEMAND is defined as a cloud-based user software and interface platform that creates the means for manufacturers and designers, experienced or novice, individual artisans or employees of major corporations, to generate wealth for their community through their work. To realize the vision of DEMAND, the core contributors of this project researched and identified experts in computer science, design, economics, manufacturing, AI, data and engineering in general, to participate in brainstorming sessions that addressed key topics and reviewed the current state-of the-art practices that affect and support our DEMAND vision. Discussions took a deep dive into how the specific topics of 1) Data and Information, 2) Secured data sharing and data trustworthiness, 3) AI for process planning and design advising, and 4) Matching algorithms, could be studied, innovated and optimized to create a method for designers and manufactures to work in more seamless harmony, and widen their potential user base.

Intellectual Merit: When analyzing and reviewing the workshop discussions, we identified two key categories:

  1. Manufacturing Data for Design: High-quality data is essential for democratization of future manufacturing and design, and knowledge transferring is the best way to connect designers and manufacturers,
  2. There is a huge amount of data from manufacturing, but far from enough for any particular issue. Data preparation faces many challenges, especially data cleaning.
  3. High-quality design-objective-related text descriptions and functional relation data for coherent applications are sparse.
  4. To closely integrate the designer and manufacturer, it is crucial to feed the designer the high-quality, real-time, dynamic process data, and to translate the manufacturing-related knowledge for the designer.
  5. A Cloud-based user software and interface platform should be developed for manufacturers and designers to share secure and trustworthy data, while protecting sensitive information and networked assets.
  6. The extraction of knowledge from the data and physics is a fundamental need, and the methods/tools for data processing need to be developed. To secure and share data, setting up a standard for systems integration is essential.

 

  1. Algorithm in Modeling: AI and machine learning are efficient tools for data searching, cleaning and analysis, and could be used for training models. To integrate manufacturing and design through AI and machine learning technologies, advanced algorithms need to be developed.
    1. To clean data and bridge physics and data, a tailored/special tool (model) is needed. The algorithms also need to be improved to enable machinery diagnosis, quality monitoring, process control and efficiency. How to properly put the constraints in the model is another key issue which needs to be solved in programming.
    2. To have efficient communication between manufacturers and designers, methods and models need to be developed to represent requirements and establish baselines to supplement guidance for manufacturers.
    3. AI technology has been used for tuning parameter settings in models, physics-informed AI for high-fidelity computational methods, and tools for complex problems to integrate design with data analysis.
    4. The algorithms need to be developed for Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) for custom manufacturing, capturing individual-specific information using AI, non-visual property modeling, and bridging communication gaps between user expression and machine interpretation.
    5. Design also involves a deeply human element to train a model to automatically extract different information to provide to designers; to develop a deep-learning driven system that retrieves design examples to support design processes: semantic-based search (text-based model), form-based search (appearance-based model), function-based search (relationship-based models).
    6. Potential applications of content analytics and NLP (Natural Language Processing) in machine learning would be a new direction to link designers and manufacturers.
    7. Algorithms for decentralized, dynamic process planning systems driven by real-time events are needed for future cloud manufacturing, which can cope with uncertainty based on bi-directional information flow. Due to potential security risks and business competition, manufacturing firms are largely unwilling to share data. Some incentives, creative ideas and improvements on data security would be helpful for encouraging resource sharing.
    8. A collection of user cases will be good to disseminate the results and stimulate the discussions and tool developments in the community. Such user cases can focus on 5-6 processes in one particular area.

 

Broader Impacts: By fostering dynamic discussions involving key experts in fields relevant to this project, we were able to conclude that advanced algorithms are essential for integrating manufacturing and design through AI. The team also concluded that high-quality data is essential for democratization of future manufacturing and design. The workshop speakers have diverse technical background as well as diverse in gender. The realization of DEMAND vision will build the necessary bridge between designers and manufacturers and integrate many disciplines.

 


Last Modified: 10/26/2021
Modified by: Jian Cao

Manufacturing Data for Design: High-quality data is essential for democratization of future manufacturing and design, and knowledge transferring is the best way to connect designers and manufacturers, 
There is a huge amount of data from manufacturing, but far from enough for any particular issue. Data preparation faces many challenges, especially data cleaning.
High-quality design-objective-related text descriptions and functional relation data for coherent applications are sparse.

Algorithm in Modeling: AI and machine learning are efficient tools for data searching, cleaning and analysis, and could be used for training models. To integrate manufacturing and design through AI and machine learning technologies, advanced algorithms need to be developed.
To clean data and bridge physics and data, a tailored/special tool (model) is needed. How to properly put the constraints in the model is another key issue which needs to be solved in programming.
To have efficient communication between manufacturers and designers, methods and models need to be developed to represent requirements and establish baselines to supplement guidance for manufacturers.
AI technology has been used for tuning parameter settings in models, physics-informed AI for high-fidelity computational methods, and tools for complex problems to integrate design with data analysis.

Algorithms for decentralized, dynamic process planning systems driven by real-time events are needed for future cloud manufacturing, which can cope with uncertainty based on bi-directional information flow. Due to potential security risks and business competition, manufacturing firms are largely unwilling to share data. Some incentives, creative ideas and improvements on data security would be helpful for encouraging resource sharing.
A collection of user cases will be good to disseminate the results and stimulate the discussions and tool developments in the community. Such user cases can focus on 5-6 processes in one particular area.
